Award.AwardTitle: The catalytic activity and mechanical stability of hollow nanoparticles (nanocages) of different sizes, shapes and shell structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Prof. Mostafa A. El-Sayed from Georgia Institute of Technology is supported by an award from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program to study catalytic activity and mechanical stability of hollow metal nanoparticles (nanocages). These come in either single or double shells and exhibit more efficient catalytic properties than solid nanoparticles. The suggestion that this enhancement arises from confinement effects is being investigated. There are several objectives in the research: 1. To compare the cage effect in gaseous reactions with those in solution. 2. To develop a plasmonically enhanced SERS technique to detect transient reaction intermediates in reactions occurring within the cavity of gold or silver nanocages. 3. To study the effects of roughening the nanocage surface and changing its shape or size on the reaction rate. 4. To explore the catalytic properties of the double shell hollow nanoparticles through developments in synthesis, comparison of electron transfer reactions with those on core-shell nanoparticles, and investigations of the alloying effect (intra-atomic diffusion between the two metallic shells). Semiconductor-metal hybrid double shell nanoparticles are being used to study photocatalysis and ultrafast electron transfer dynamics using femtosecond pump-probe techniques. 5. The mechanical stability of the nanocages having plasmonic nanoshells is determined using the group's ultrafast lattice coherent oscillation method as a function of the metals used, shell thickness, degree of the alloying process

Catalysis is a $900 billion field and is responsible for the more efficient production of over 90% of consumer materials. Nanocatalysis is a rapidly expanding field and could have important impacts on numerous technical fields such as chemical production, sustainable energy, and materials chemistry. The research proposed here has the potential to find new catalysts of industrial importance. The research will not be limited to nanocatalysis research, but will include introducing a new technique based on femtosecond dynamics to measure the mechanical strength of the nanocages used. This work is being carried out by their Laser Dynamics Lab, which frequently provides collaboration and help to other scientists and engineers needing to measure ultrafast dynamics in nanoparticle systems. The lab is very active in educating postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate students. Usually half of the undergraduates, including those in the NNIN and/or REU summer program, are females or minorities. The group maintains good relationships with the faculties at these neighboring minority-serving schools and the PI regularly gives seminars there, while the Laser Dynamics Laboratory is on the Georgia Tech list of laboratories that are open to visiting groups of students and teachers from the local community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the previous years of support we have prepared and studied new designs of nanoparticle catalysts. Below is a list of our accomplishments:

1-     Preparing nanocatalysts composed of two metals and with an optional semiconductor in two different structures (double shells and rattle). This approach, based on the galvanic replacement technique, was used to prepare palladium-gold, platinum-gold, and gold-gold nanorattles with different sizes. The optical properties of the nanorattles were studied experimentally by a single particle measurement technique and theoretically using the discrete dipole approximation. Gold nanospheres and palladium, platinum, or gold nanoshells have a single localized surface plasmon resonance. This peak is sharp for gold nanospheres and broad for palladium or platinum.  Interestingly, when these particles were combined into a nanorattle structure, the modes hybridize producing new exciting optical properties. The interesting and useful optical properties of the prepared nanorattles added to their useful catalytic properties.  

2-     The double shells and rattle nanoparticles exhibited good catalytic properties and so the origin of their catalytic efficiency was investigated. Confinement of intermediates inside the cavity of the hollow nanocatalyst, change in Fermi level energy position, and optical generation of radicals were found to be important factors. Reduction of 4-nitrophenol by sodium borohydride was used as a model reaction to examine the change in the catalytic efficiency of the gold palladium nanorattles of different dimensions. As raising the heat of a chemical reaction increases its rate, photo-excitation of the gold nanoparticle located inside the palladium shell of the gold palladium nanorattle was found to increase its catalytic efficiency through photothermal heating of the surrounding medium.

3-     The mechanism of heterogeneous redox catalysis on the surface of gold nanoshells was spectroscopically studied. The presence of plasmonic gold surfaces made it possible to detect any small changes that took place on the surfaces of the nanoshell catalysts and monitor the rate of reaction using surface-enhanced Raman measurements.

4-     Two graduate students were trained in how to engineer the design of the catalyst to reduce the production cost and to obtain the highest possible efficiency. This training involved synthesis of the catalysts by colloidal chemical techniques and examining the catalytic efficiency of the catalysts. Quite recently, these two graduate students received their Ph.Ds. One is working for BASF in the USA, and the other is a postdoctoral researcher at TUM, Munich, Germany.

5-     Two undergraduate students have been trained on how to synthesize the nanoparticles by colloidal chemical techniques.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/12/2016
Modified by: Mostafa A El-Sayed
